notesStmt.note: First flyleaf is loose from binding; darker discoloration on 18v; script is faded on several leaves, including 59v-60r; 65v-66r, 68r, 73v, and 89v; some wear to outer edge of binding.
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York,: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2047, no. 123.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Free Library, 1937), pp. 92-93, no. 84.

Rosenbach Museum and Library, Sixty Bokes Olde and Newe: Manuscripts and Early Printed Books from Libraries in and Near Philadelphia Illustrating Chaucer's Sources, His Works and their Influence, exhibition catalogue. (Knoxville, TN: New Chaucer Society, 1986), pp. 69-72, no. 40.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is a fourteenth-century theological miscellany written in England. This manuscript contains a collection of theological writings, including Book III of Gregory the Great's Moralia in Job, an anonymous treatise entitled Summa de trinitate, Hugh of St. Cher's Speculum ecclesiae (Mirror of the Church), and Innocent III's De miseria conditionis humanae (On the misery of the human condition).

msItem.title: "Ibimus" paraphrase of Robert of Sorbon's De tribus dietis paradisi
msItem.incipit: Ibimus uia[m] t[rium] die[rum] in solitudi[n]e ut i[m]molemus d[omi]no deo n[ost]ro [Exodus 3:18]
msItem.explicit: Ad quem nos per ducat qui est benedictus i[n] s[a]ecula s[a]eculor[um] amen. [fol. 55r]

msItem.title: Robert of Sorbon? De septem homicidiis
msItem.explicit: De absolon qui multitudi[n]e capillor[um] suor[um] inhesit ... fuit p[er] multitudine[m] capillor[um] multitudo t[em]p[o]ral[u]m significatum p[er] habundantiam. Explicit summa pe[n]itencie. [fol. 85r]

msItem.title: Gregory the Great, Moralia in Job, Book III
msItem.incipit: Beatus iob ad morte[m] petitus i[n] temptatione ad uita[m] creuit ex uebere
msItem.explicit: In ip[s]o namq[ue] operis hi[jus] exordio uelut i[n] molem nascit[ura]e arboris lingu[a]e radice[m] fixum[us]...prout singula expetunt loca producamus. Explicit tercius liber de moralia beati gregorii sup[er] libro iob. [fol. 104r]

msItem.title: (Pseudo-) Bernard of Clairvaux, Meditationes
msItem.incipit: Multi multa sciunt et se ip[s]os nesciunt.
msItem.explicit: uideas etiam meridianum solem iusticie in quo sponsum cum sponsa prospicies ... et regnat deus per omn[i]a s[ae]c[u]la. Expliciunt meditationes beati bernardi abbatis [fol. 118r]

msItem.title: Anonymous, Summa de trinitate
msItem.incipit: De trinitate hoc tene[n]dum e[st] quod in una s[u]bstancia sunt tres p[er]sone s[cilicet] p[ate]r et fili[us] et spiritus sanctus
msItem.explicit: ...non ex solo pane uiuit homo sed ex omni u[er]bo quod procedit ex ore dei. Explicit su[m]ma de t[r]initate. [fol. 134r]

msItem.title: Hugh of St. Cher, Speculum ecclesie
msItem.incipit: Dicit apostolus ad ephe[sios]. ui. cap[itul]o. Induite nos armatura dei ut possitis stare adu[er]sus insidias dyaboli.
msItem.explicit: [Ends imperfectly] ...ut om[n]e sacrificium sordidatum uetustate igne comburendu[m] est [fol. 146v]

msItem.title: Innocent III, De miseria conditionis humanae
msItem.incipit: qu[a]e non expediunt. fiet cibus ignis. Esca u[er]mis massa put[re]dinis. Exponam illud plani[us] et dicam plenius.
msItem.explicit: ...torsiones et co[m]punctiones. amaritudi[n]es et terrores. fames sitis. frigus et cauma sulfur ignis in s[ae]c[u]la s[ae]c[u]lor[um] amen. Explicit liber mis[er]ie conditionis humane d[e]o gra[ci]as. [fol. 170v]

msItem.title: Leaf from a Dutch Book of Hours?

supportDesc.extent: iii+172+iii; 223 x 154 mm bound to 229 x 167 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Original foliation in red ink occurs in upper recto margin starting on folio 12r with e.xviii and progressing through alphabetic letters to i.xx; h xxxiii and h xxxiv are missing; modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto and lower right recto; references in this entry are to upper right recto; folio 133 is numbered twice

layoutDesc.layout: Written area 151 x 103 mm, pricking visible; two columns of thirty-six lines, lead point ruling; fourteen full foliate borders with decorated initials; numerous small decorated initials throughout; paragraph markers alternate blue with red flourishing and gold with blue flourishing; capital letters are highlighted in yellow; guide letters for the rubrics and foliation visible throughout along with occasional Latin marginal annotations; tipped into the support pages is a single leaf from what may be a Dutch book of hours

decoDesc.decoNote: No illustrations; fourteen folios have full foliate borders with decorated initials in gold, ink, and paint (ff. 1r, 4r, 32v (showing arms of Malmesbury Abbey?), 55v, 57r, 59v, 66v, 73r, 75v, 78r, 85v, 104r, 118r, 134r).
Inside front coverBookplate, George F. Leighton
1rIlluminated initial I and full foliate border
55vIlluminated initial M and full foliate border
57rIlluminated initial P and full foliate border
59vIlluminated initial S and full foliate border
66vIlluminated initial Q and full foliate border
72rIlluminated initial Q and full foliate border
78rIlluminated initial S and full foliate border
85vIlluminated initial B and full foliate border
104rDecorated initial M and full foliate border
118rDecorated initial D and full foliate border
134rDecorated initial D and full foliate border

binding.p: Nineteenth-century, green levant morocco, blind tooled to an Aldine design on the sides and back, gilt edges, by Pierre Marcellin Lortic; "LIBER MISERÆ CONDITIONIS HUMANE. MS CIRCA XIVme" stamped in gold on spine

history.provenance: Malmesbury Abbey; Collection of George F. Leighton, Saint Louis, sold 1929; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; fol. 32 contains arms of the Abbey of Malmesbury in the border (gues two leopards argent, a chief argent, over all an episopal crozier in pale; bookplate for George L. Leighton, Saint Louis, on inside cover; auction notes in front flyleaf, with tipped-in auction catalogue description (in French) for lot 276; a catalogue entry for lot 83 (English) has been tipped into final endpapers, with "600 Bought 725" written the margin
